Traveler

The law which Bush signed provides that any person who causes death or injury to a child in the womb shall be charged with a seperate offense, in addition to any charges relating to the mother.
 
 A person who assaults a pregnant woman and injures or kills her baby can be federally charged with a seperate charge for the injury or death of her child in addition to any injury he/she may have caused to the mother
 
 At the link I provided, click on H.R. 1997 and you can read to your hearts content. 
 
 There you and everyone else can follow this bill from its start and can follow Kerry on it, too.
 
 Bush signed H.R. 1997, Laci and Conner's Law, which passed on March 25, 2004, into law on 4/1/2004. 
 
 Thank God for President Bush's leadership!

I think the reason for Kerry's vote was spelled out quite clearly by dsadevil in the "Conservatives Unite Against Bush" thread.
 
 Here's the exchange -
 
 
DSADEVIL - Kerry votes NAY on "Laci and Conner's Law" which would allow for a seperate murder charge for the killing of a fetus if its done in the attack of a pregnant women. The democrats charged that this was a cynical ploy to create a legislative history recognizing a fetus as a "person" and that the goals of the bill could just as easily be achieved by making the killing of fetus an aggrevating factor in sentencing. I lean pro-life, so I'm not outright opposed to the labeling of a fetus as a living person. But that makes the vote defensable in my view.

 
 
JIM'S TRUCKING - A fetus is a person. Kerry said recently that he believes life begins at conception. How can he justify this vote to not punish someone who murders a fetus? Is he flipping again? 
 
 
 
DSADEVIL - Once again, I answered this. Sen. Kerry is in favor of punishing someone who murders a fetus, its just a question of methodology. To the extent that Kerry is pro-choice (im sure u disagree with that stance), a preferable way to go about punishing someone is by making the death of a fetus an aggrevating factor in a crime, rather than simply defining the fetus as a seperate person. I honestly don't have a problem with this vote, since the end result is the same. Indeed, I'm a bit annoyed the republicans are playing politics with this, since there was a bipartisan, non-controversial idea on the table to accomplish the same goal as this bill, but the GOP felt compelled to pick an election year fight.

 
 Again, as was dsadevil's point at the beginning of this exchange, anything can be taken out of context and spun if you so desire to do so. You'd do well to take a look at the thread this exchange is from if you haven't already.

I's like to see Kerry spin his way out of this issue.
 
  The Unborn Victims Of Violence Act provides that under federal law, any person who causes death or injury to a child in the womb shall be charged with a seperate offense, in addition to any charges relating to the mother.
 
 Violence against women often does have two victims, and the second victim(baby) should be protected as well. If some thug hits a pregnant woman and she and the baby dies he should be charged with two murders. This law provides for that.
dsadevil

Wow, I'm being quoted! That's pretty cool actually.
 
 Traveler, I'll try and put Sen. Kerry's vote in a context you can understand. The democratic alternative to Laci and Conner's bill (or more precisely, the amendment they put forward to the bill) was the Lofgren (D-CA) Amendment in the house. I don't know if Republican leaders ever let a similar amendment come to the floor in the senate, but it was the primary democratic alternative. As I stated earlier, the purpose of this amendment was to make the killing of a pregnant women (and her fetus) an aggrevating factor in the crime, thus subject to stiffer punishments, rather than simply making it two seperate crimes. As such, your statement that the only acceptable way to democrats to handle this bill was to scuttle it is factually inaccurate.
 
 The reason for this, again as I said earlier, is that Democrats didn't want to create a legislative track history for recognizing a fetus as a "person," because if it is a person than presumably it should get all the protections afforded to persons under our constitution (essentially overruling Roe v. Wade). Would the passage of this bill, alone, cause Roe to be overturned? Doubtfully. But it definitely is a step in that direction. Since the Democratic proposal would have had the same end result (in that people who killed pregnant women and fetus's would be punished more severely) in a far less controversial manner, I don't understand why Republican's would want to push for a more controversial bill UNLESS they were gunning for an election year fight.
 
 The importance of a legislative track history in terms of the legal status of a fetus cannot be underestimated. Indeed, as the court wrote in Roe v. Wade (410 US 113, 156-158 1973)
 
The appellee and certain amici argue that the fetus is a "person" within the language and meaning of the Fourteenth Amendment. In support of this, they outline at length and in detail the well-known facts of fetal development. If this suggestion of personhood is established, the appellant's case, of course, collapses, for the fetus' right to life would then be guaranteed specifically by the Amendment. The appellant conceded as much on reargument. On the other hand, the appellee conceded on reargument that no case could be cited that holds that a fetus is a person within the meaning of the Fourteenth Amendment. 
 
 The Constitution does not define "person" in so many words. Section 1 of the Fourteenth Amendment contains three references to "person." The first, in defining "citizens," speaks of "persons born or naturalized in the United States." The word also appears both in the Due Process Clause and in the Equal Protection Clause. "Person" is used in other places in the Constitution: in the listing of qualifications for Representatives and Senators, Art. I, 2, cl. 2, and 3, cl. 3; in the Apportionment Clause, Art. I, 2, cl. 3; 53 in the Migration and Importation provision, Art. I, 9, cl. 1; in the Emolument Clause, Art. I, 9, cl. 8; in the Electors provisions, Art. II, 1, cl. 2, and the superseded cl. 3; in the provision outlining qualifications for the office of President, Art. II, 1, cl. 5; in the Extradition provisions, Art. IV, 2, cl. 2, and the superseded Fugitive Slave Clause 3; and in the Fifth, Twelfth, and Twenty-second Amendments, as well as in 2 and 3 of the Fourteenth Amendment. But in nearly all these instances, the use of the word is such that it has application only postnatally. None indicates, with any assurance, that it has any possible pre-natal application.
 
 All this, together with our observation, supra, that throughout the major portion of the 19th century prevailing legal abortion practices were far freer than they are today, persuades us that the word "person," as used in the Fourteenth Amendment, does not include the unborn. 

 
 The lack of compelling evidence that congress/framers meant for the unborn to be included in the context of a "person" was a key pillar on which the holding in Roe rested on.
Waxy

I's like to see Kerry spin his way out of this issue.
 
  The Unborn Victims Of Violence Act provides that under federal law, any person who causes death or injury to a child in the womb shall be charged with a seperate offense, in addition to any charges relating to the mother.
 
 Violence against women often does have two victims, and the second victim(baby) should be protected as well. If some thug hits a pregnant woman and she and the baby dies he should be charged with two murders. This law provides for that.

 
 You seem unable, or perhaps unwilling, to recognize how loaded the wording of that Act is when it comes to pro-life vs. pro-choice. You're pro-life, that's obvious, but does that blind you to logic and reason? There's no spin needed at all, just a belief in pro-choice. One can easily be against violence against women and at the same time, pro-choice. IMHO, it's you that's spinning Kerry's vote into something it's not. You're suggesting that Kerry is soft on violence against women and children because he voted nay on one loaded bill. That's preposterous.
 
 The filing of a separate charge on behalf of the fetus make the fetus a person by default, complete with all the rights attached to being a person. It sets a precedent as such within the legal system, a precedent that could, and WILL, be used as grounds for legal challenges of a fetus's rights as a person.
 
 Are you really unable to see how that could have an affect, both in the short term, and in the long term, when it comes to the abortion issue?
 
 Further to that, it's clear to me that you didn't read the other thread, and dsadevil's point on how easy it is to spin these votes or comments.
 
 Waxy
Waxy

I fail to see just how this law could have been worded any different to make this acceptable to all. 

 
 Simply put, that's your failure.
 
 Again, right from the quote of dsadevil in my first post -
 
 
a preferable way to go about punishing someone is by making the death of a fetus an aggrevating factor in a crime, rather than simply defining the fetus as a seperate person.

 
 Seems simple enough, and I'm sure it could be expounded upon so as to be very tough on violence against women and unborn fetuses.

 "any person who causes death or injury to a child in the womb shall be charged with a separate offense".
 
 Not only does this open the door to the complete reversal of Rowe v. Wade, it also could subject doctors to murder charges - and not just abortion doctors. Complications during pregnancy and delivery occur all the time and now there is a law to better help this sue-happy society we live in.
 
 Open your mind and really read the words written into the law, not just your interpretation of them.

There is a topic about this in the Abortion forum.
 
 Here is another aspect of the bill that may be why Kerry voted against it:
 
 
Because the UVVA[Unborn Victims of Violence Act] is a Federal Bill, it cannot actually be used in any murder
 case, which would fall under State Law. This would make the UVVA
 ineffectual in actually protecting a pregnant woman, but create a stepping
 stone for a national ban on abortion. An alternate version of the bill,
 which recognizes the pregnant woman as the victim, and includes a provision
 to the Tenth Amendment (States Rights), was voted against by the same people
 who voted for the UVVA.
 

 
 It was simply a case of Republicans playing politics, not actually trying to save lives. John Kerry voted for the alternative bill, which would actually do some good.
